review_body: This place is GROSS!!! Carpets are stained and sticky. Vents are full of dust and dirt. Very old and dated building. Blankets have holes. I've stayed in Motel 8's better than this!

Waikiki Grand Condo #206 Owner JerryThe Condo was great--a little on the small side but the amenities made up for that. Gerry made us feel so welcome, starting with the Lei greeting, down to everything he supplied the condo with. It was an extremely comfortable location for us. We have traveled to Waikiki many times and now we are both retired so we are seeking different types of accommodations. Well not one once of disappointment in these accommodations! Beautifully appointed, great location, wonderful sundeck, and the most gorgeous view of Diamond Head!

I have travelled to Hawaii quite a few times in recent years and chose this hotel having checked it out on a previous visit. All of the previous reviews are correct - the quality of the room you get depends on who owns the apartment. I stayed in room 608 and it had been recently renovated with flatscreen Television, granite bench tops, full size fridge, great balcony, views of Diamond Head, the Park and the Ocean.Yes, there is a gay bar on the second floor but very little noise travels up and I found the people staying here to be friendly. The location is hard to beat with fantastic views and close to everything. I think the critical comments about this hotel are overstated. I found it clean and generally well-maintained. The pool is not much to speak about but the free internet connection, kitchenette facilities, location, and fantastic price make this a good choice. I booked this hotel online and everything went smoothly.

Pros: (1) Great location, right across from Waikiki beach; (2) Great roofdeck for clear view of Diamond Head and ocean, perfect for viewing sunrise/sunset; (3) Good value (we paid $89/night incl taxes for a 4-night stay); (4) Hula's gay bar on 2nd floorCons: (1) Cockroaches & bugs in bathroom & small kitchenette--gross!; (2) Old, used furniture, including subpar mattress; (3) No room service or regular housekeeping service; (4) Front desk staff not as friendly or knowledgeable as they should be

We knew the area and loved the bar so were excited to try the hotel. It's old and pretty laid back but it was perfect for our three night stay. No maid service but I am sure we could have gotten supplies/towels if we'd askedGreat kitchen set up with dishes and silverware. Coffeepot but no coffee but ABC Store is just next door.Room was small but SPOTLESS! We've stayed in other Castle properties and this is not always the caseWe loved it for the value, the location and the fun

This place is REVOLTING! We stayed here twice, at the beginning and end of our trip to Hawaii - and we would never stay here again. Both units we stayed in were filthy and smelly. I had booked and paid for 2 adults and 2 children, only to be allocated a room with ONE double bed. Staff could not have cared less about this and were very unhelpful. We were expected to sleep on the floor. Definitely NOT a place to stay with the family, with the gay bar downstairs pumping until 2am and gay couples canoodling in the elevators. Swimming pool was revolting - there was no way i was letting the kids swim in that. Don't consider staying here unless you meet someone in the gay bar downstairs and hire a room by the hour.....

The Waikiki Grand is in an OPTIMUM location, 1/2 block from the beach and an ABC Store below for any of your everyday needs. The Hula Bar on the second floor rocks and the drinks are reasonable, there are many people of different persuasions and that's cool. There is no need to worry. Teddy's Bigger Burgers is on the ground floor and they provide a tasty treat when you are in the need.The Hotel has primarily owner rented units and chances are you will be staying in an individual's investment property. My wife and I lucked out and managed to get Unit 905 owned by Jerry and Mike. This was a gem of a unit, Kitchenette, tiled floor throughout, and just too many amenities to list. There is no room service or linen service but you should be provided,as we were, with extra linens and towels. There is washer and dryer in the basement so don't be shy. We had a great time!!!There is no Free Parking but the front desk girl directed me to parking for 10/day-in and out.

Okay, I give up! Are people really that crazy giving this dump a positive recommendation? How did they get to their "fabulous" rooms? Were they completely oblivious to the filthy hallways, the rundown elevators(one was out of order). The seedy pool area and the ROACHES!!!!? I guess some people have no idea what a decent hotel is supposed to look like, or their standards are incredibly low. All kinds of red flags should have gone up when I saw the price, but being a first time visitor to the area, and only spending two nights in Honolulu, I thought it would be acceptable. My impression while driving around the island is that very little is done to maintain properties, the homeless frequent public areas and parks, and perhaps, had I gone to a resort away from Waikiki Beach, I might have found better lodging. If you want a tropical paradise, don't waste your time in Honolulu. It is just a big city with palm trees, crumbling infrastructure, and shacks for residences. My final thoughts are that locals have no sense of cleanliness, lack manners, and love/breed roaches...Mahala, but no Mahala. Thank God, I spent the remainder of the vacation on Maui, otherwise, if this was my only impression of the fiftieth state, then may a lava spewing volcano cover it over. Then maybe, they could start all over, although the roaches probably would still survive.

We met someone in the elevator that said they were unhappy with their room, but ours was spottless with a wall mounted flat screen TV ( only local channels)- but who goes for the TV. Looks like a newly renovated room. The walk is 50 yards to the beach. And you have never seen Diamond Head until you view it from the Lania (forgot to mention the Ocean view). Internet was fast, but you need an ethernet cable or go to Starbucks on the corner. It has to be the best room for the price. the room is small the the King, but we spent most of our time gone or on the Lanai.

Why anyone would stay in a more expensive hotel when this place offers a million-dollar view at a bargain price is beyond me! Unit 614 is located next to the elevators but I never heard a peep - I was too busy sitting on the lanai gaping at the ocean view and occasionally turning to my left to gaze at Diamond Head to the accompanying sounds of the exotic birds at the Honolulu Zoo across the street. The unit itself is a cozy studio on Kapahulu overlooking Kapiolani Park (NOTE: this IS where the action is, with a gay bar on the 3rd floor. The noisy garbage pickup every morning can be annoying - pull the pillow over your head. It's over soon.) The kitchen has basic cooking facilities consisting of a microwave, two-burner hotplate, toaster, and coffeemaker plus a minifridge. Drawbacks: no kitchen sink, freezer compartment is very limited. Bathroom was nice and roomy with a square tub. The units in this hotel are individually owned, so you have residents and guests hsaring the space, which has the feel of a moderate-price apartment complex. This is no luxury unit and if you are looking for in-room perks and pampering, you want one of those pricier rooms elsewhere, but was comfortable and clean and oh-so-convenient; the view made it worth everything! (Not all units have this particular view, but the Diamond Head side does.) It was late April and I turned the AC on only once - Sheryl Crow played the Waikiki Shell and we listened to her voice drifting over the palms. I lived in Honolulu many years ago, and this sweet spot is primo tourist location with all the perks. An ABC Store just outside the open-air lobby has most anything you want. Grab a bottle of wine or beer and some snacks, then turn the TV to the local guide channel, close the cabinet doors, and enjoy real Hawaiian music while you bask in that million-dollar view!

Got a corner studio on the 4th floor. Checked in around 9p and the front desk was already waiting for me with a key. On a bus service (Roberts of Hawaii), I lucked out since I was the first drop off coming out of Hwy1, at the far end of Waikiki closer to Diamond Head.Great apartment with a working kitchen and a sofabed. Sad I didn't stay longer to use all the facilities since I'm on a 11hr layover. Rumor has it the adjacent property (Queen Kapiolani) will be managing it going forward. The rates will go higher if this happens. At the moment, the kama-aina (local resident) rates are higher than the promo rate of USD75 per night.
