review_body: I booked the Grand basically for its location because I wanted to be close to Queens Beach. It's important to remember that the Grand is individually owned condo's which may or may not have been updated or renovated. I think it’s very important that you choose the right room and hence why such a variety of responses and reviews on trip advisor. I made my booking direct with the Grand and in my initial enquiry asked about the various rooms and which ones they would recommend. I specifically request a room with a balcony and was given room 501. My friends were booked into room 621 and said it was a dump and very old and outdated. Another friend of mine had room 622 which was well maintained with new furniture plus a slightly larger room, nice island kitchen, updated bathroom, but with no balcony or view. He was very happy with his room... it was clean and well maintained and obviously the owner had taken pride in his condo.Room 501 (my room) - consists of one large room with queens size bed and bar style kitchen all in one, separate hand wash basin and walk thru to toilet and shower / bath.On Arrival - Room hadn't been cleaned properly and had to request the main desk to send the cleaner up to wash the floors. My feet were black after walking around my room within 20 minutes. This was promptly taken care of and my floors were quickly mopped down. Bedding - was ok but I believe it could do with a new base and mattress and new pillows. There is no daily room service and for any change of sheets or towels you must now request this from the front reception office. Furnishings knocked around a bit and draws broken and not closing. Well equipped kitchen with full length fridge, coffee maker, cups, plates and utensils. I did wake up one night to find cockroaches in the bathroom. This didn't really disturb me as I'm aware how hard it is to eradicate these pests and is to be expected in tropical areas. If I had to complain it would be the noise generated from the restaurant on the ground level. Out the back they have some type of exhaust / fan that seems to run continuously. Not a problem during the day but at night it seemed to vibrate through my room. The Grand does have a pool, but I never saw one person use it. It’s not really in a prominent location and is rather run down and I believe the owners are looking at upgrading the pool area in the future.The reception and staff were all very friendly and helpful when requesting information. I wouldn’t say the Grand is a Gay hotel, but more gay friendly. There was a good mix of clientele ranging from young to older, gays, and couples etc all of which were very friendly. On the second level is the night club hula’s, which is a Gay night club and I don’t believe this interfered with the actual running of the hotel in any way. There are lots of little restaurants and ABC shops located in easy walking distance from the Grand. You can forget going to the Gay beach at Queens Beach or the Queen Kapolani Park. Unfortunately due to the current economical climate there are a lot of homeless people and beggars hanging around this area and actually camping there during the day and night. Whilst walking along the esplanade to Queens beach I was confronted by beggars asking for money and cigarettes constantly. I was even abused by a few when I declined. Definitely not an area to be walking around at night either as they bed down around the toilet blocks and throughout the park and a lot of them are drunk and it could be quite dangerous. The police are continually patrolling the area, but I guess there’s only so much they can do. I would suggest the beach at the lighthouse up at Diamond Head for guys looking for a safe area to sun bake. It’s about a 15 minute walk from Queens Beach.As a gay destination I don’t believe I would travel the distance to Hawaii again, it’s changed considerably since my last stay there almost 10 years ago. I would recommend the Grand to fellow travelers as long as you keep in mind that this is a budget accommodation and you get what you pay for.

I reserved an ocean view suite - when I got to the room, it was a very small room, with a "kitchen" in the closet. You had to move the bed to get to the closet. I was told it was one of their "larger" rooms. The windows were so dirty you couldn't see out of them, there was dust and dirt on the floor. I didn't want to leave my luggage there let alone stay in the room. I was also informed the hotel was full and to check back on the weekend to move. I went down to the front desk and immediately upon complaining they gave me keys for 3 other rooms which were just a touch better than room 412. If I hadn't prepaid for the entire stay I would have left and went to another hotel. Be wary of this hotel, they are individually owned rooms and vary from pathetic to barely pathetic. I will NEVER stay there again or let my friends stay there. My worst travel experience in 30 years!!!

Be Aware that this is a Gay Hotel and Lounge. So be prepared, also its very noise and very old with bad pluming. lots of crickets in all rooms, you can smell the insecticide at all times. Bottom line stay away unless you are a gay on a budget !!!!

Worse sleeping room I have ever stayed in!Grungy. dirty, bad bed, poor pillows, TV remote did not work, poor service.Toilet did not work.There was a notice in our room that in a week they would no longer provide housekeeping services. You had to go to the desk for linens.Positives: Nice lobby. Great location.You are better sleeping on the beach.

This room felt like Hawaii. the price was right and the room was spotlessly clean. I saw a few other rooms and each is individualize, but we still like this room the best. Great TV, wet/ bar and nice carpeting. The beach and main drag of Waikiki are within a 1/2 block away, and the zoo and one of Americas largest parks is just across the street. Though it's obviously not a 5 star hotel - for the price it can't be beat, and since I don't spend much time in the room- it was a clean, well-fitted, efficient place to hang my hat for 2 weeks.

This review is specifically related to Unit #908 at the Waikiki Grand Hotel. The unit is privately owned and taken care of in every way. We knew the view was great from the pictures on the website, but were could not have imagined it being so breathtaking in person. The unit had everything and I mean everything you could want during your stay. Flat screen TV, stereo, wireless internet, kitchen, couch, bar stools, A/C, a wonderfully decorated bathroom and a lanai that features the best view in Waikiki. The owners also let you use the boogie boards, umbrella, beach towels, beach chairs, goggles and blow up rafts free of charge.You're right across the street from the Honolulu Zoo (don't worry, there isn't a whole lot of animal noise, no worries), but that means your view is unobstructed from the ocean and Diamond Head Crater. There isn't another hotel across the street that you have to look at and no one looking in at you either. Every morning we woke up and had breakfast on the lanai and enjoyed a view that we'll never forget. This place is worth every penny and if we go back, there isn't another place we would stay.You won't be disappointed in Unit #908. It is fantastic!

We had a 6 night vacation planed and only stayed in this hotel three nights too long before checking out. The room was not what we expected and the way we were treated with such disrespect from the night security (Morales) who just happen to shoved his name badge in my face (twice) when I asked his name to file a complaint about him after he threatened to call the police on us while we were finishing up a smoke on the sidewalk after coming back from a walk. We were in front of the building getting ready to go back up to our room 1008 (horrible view). We are on vacation coming from another state where we did not know the "strict" restrictions on smoking in front of this jail (Waikiki Grand) and the way the night time security approached us and threatened us was just crazy. We even told him we were staying there and all he said was "I don't care, if I see you smoking here again I will call the police for trespassing".The next morning we woke up to find a rules and regulations notice on our door with the smoking law highlighted. Disrespectful and embarrassing. There is NO mention of “no smoking” in the front of the hotel. We talked with the manager (Don) of the building, this guy was not any better, before we could even open our mouths to tell him what happened, he said are you in room 1008 and we said yes, he said I talked to the security and that's that law! When we finally told him about the incident, all he did was just try to make excuses for this guy. Not once did anyone say sorry. When we mentioned that we were uncomfortable and thinking about going somewhere else, he just said you are more than welcome to leave and stay next door (which we did). Instead of trying to make things better he made is worst. We ended up staying in the next building (Park Shore Hotel) and what a beautiful view and the customer service was outstanding, and it was cheaper and cleaner. What a difference this made in our last 3 days of our vacation. As far as the Waikiki Grand... I highly do NOT recommend this place, the staff is rude and needs to go, and they need some major cleaning service and a customer service oriented security (night shift). And BTW they have security cameras everywhere it is like being in jail not on a vacation

We booked this hotel not expecting great things given the mixed reviews, but found the location perfect for us. It was an extremely short walk to the beach, had the park and zoo right across the road and Diamond Head only about a mile away. No - it wasn't terribly close to the shops, but nothing is really too far away from anything else in this place! The front desk staff were nice and friendly, our room was a little worn but generally well kept. It was a little noisy, but the louvre windows were great for getting fresh air into the room. Not the place for a pamper or romantic secluded getaway - but anyone who is expecting this sort of thing in Waikiki needs to be paying a whole lot more for their accommodation!

First, you have to understand the concept of this hotel. It is an old hotel, built in the sixties, which has been converted into a studio condo hotel, in which private owners, own the units either for rental investments or for personal use. When owners are not using their units themselves, they can rent them through the Hotel service or through private management companies. I have stayed many times in the past 5yrs at this property, I have been to Hawaii 23 times. I can tell you from first hand experience, it all depends on who you rent from, whether or not you will have a good or bad experience. Let me explain. I have found the best units in the building are the ones managed by anyone other than Queens Surf!!! I recently stayed in unit 918, for 22 nights and it by far is the best most well maintained unit that I have had the chance to experience. Many times I have rented from Queens Surf vacation rentals and the majority of reviews I have read on this web sight are things that I have experienced as well. However, just to let people know, this is a great location in Waikiki, it is in the heart of everything, you can stay here with or without a car, just out the front of the building is all sorts of options for transportation, from taxi's to the major routes for the bus systems to shuttle services. As far as the hotel, you just have to do your research, you can find great units here, just don't limit yourself to only one option for the condo units. Google, Waikiki Grand, or look for other rental services at the Grand, you can find better and more reasonable units in this great quaint condotel property. I would suggest trying units 302,319,605 or 918. I have seen and inspected all of these particular units and they are of the best quality in this building and the most well maintained for cleanliness and well appointed with every amenity needed for your stay while in Hawaii. In the basement of the building there is also a laundry facility that is available 24hrs a day. This is very accommodating, now that the airlines are restricting the amount of luggage you can check free of charge. I truely hope this review will assist you in making your trip to Paradise a very enjoyable one. I have to say that I am a very picky traveler, I have a degree in the hospitality and airline career industry. I have worked many years in the business of travel myself and know what to expect for the value of my travel dollar. My only suggestion is once again, do your homework and research and I am sure you will enjoy your stay at "THE WAIKIKI GRAND"!!!!! Aloha, and Happy Travels to the Islands

The check in clerk "Freddy" was very unfriendly and had poor customer service. The lobby area was nice but the hotel itself is old and out of date. As I give my experience to you please keep in mind that I am pregnant during this time..... The first room they gave me had a dirty tub that didn't drain properly, so I they changed my room after dragging my items to a second room, the second room had dried up urine on the toliet and they woke me up first thing the next morning doing repairs on the elevator which was right next to my room! I also forgot to add when I went to use the phone to ask about all the noise I found out that my phone in my room didn't work. I went down stairs and was told they would send someone up. Three hours later... after not hearing from anyone I went back down stair and was told the phone company would have to come out but could not come out until the next day to fix the phone so I would need to move a third time, to a THIRD room this room was better but it still had bad plumbing. I just gave up but I will never spend my money there again!

We stayed in #920, a privately owned studio for 1 week in April. The location was perfect--the view from the 10th floor sundeck was amazing. The beach, the zoo and Kapiolani park were all right across the street. Bus lines right in front of the hotel and we were able to do without renting a car.The night we got in the owner of the condo called to make sure everything was fine. That was great. Everything was just fine, not a 5 star hotel but perfect for my husband and myself. The condo was clean, bed comfortable and the well equipped kitchenette made it convenient for breakfasts and quick snacks.The price was right for us who would rather spend the extra money on sight seeing and touring, etc. Just a note, yes there is a gay bar in the hotel on the 2nd floor, but we were up on the 9th so if there was any noise it certainly did not bother us. (And the hotel does not only cater to gays--there were other husband-wife teams there as well). We would recommend this studio to our friends and we certainly would go back. This was our first trip to Hawaii and we totally loved it. (And not one cockroach was seen as some of the other negative reviews stated!)

It never ceases to amaze me when people expect more than what they pay for. Previous reviews of the Waikiki Grand highlight the importance of researching your accommodation to have a realistic expectation of what to expect.We spent 6 nights at the Waikiki Grand Hotel - I looked around and it was the best deal we could find for our budget (Originally I wanted to stay at the Royal Grove Hotel, but it was sold out). We were strictly trying to stay to a $100 per night limit. A few things to help anyone thinking of staying here.....Yes, there is a gay bar! But who cares really - you don't have to go if you don't want to. Some people are still very ignorant to the gay community - it's not like they are going to chase you down and convert you! In this day and age people really need to 'get over it'.Yes, there is noise - especially the garbage trucks! It happened twice during our stay. But hey - its $95 per night with housekeeping included! It's also Waikiki! Things happen at night here with people coming back from the nightclubs etc - stay outside of Waikiki if you can't handle the noise!Yes, the rooms are small. The carpet was very badly stained (we were in room 620) and the kitchen and bathroom was very small. But as I said before, we were using the room only to sleep and shower - it was clean and that's the important thing. However, as a note to Management the carpet needs to be replaced in this room as it is a bit of a joke, but not 'un-liveable'.If you are a young couple (of any sexual orientation) who would like some privacy and stay somewhere which is a few steps up from a hostel, this is the place for you! If you are older, have kids, don't like noise stay somewhere else and fork out the money for what you want!!!And remember..... you get what you pay for, so for $95 per night don't complain!

Rented a condo for the week. Location was okay. We did a LOT of walking as the hub of Waikiki was a mile away. It would have been nice to know that the bar on the second floor of this hotel is known to the locals as the gay bar in Waikiki. There is even a gay flag on one of the poles at this hotel. Honestly, we felt like we were staying at a gay youth hostel. I would not recommend this hotel for families with children. The rooms are VERY small. My husband and I were very cramped just the two of us. We had both a queen size bed and a sitting area; except the bed was a murphy bed and you could either have the bed down and stack up the sitting furniture (some ended up on the lanai), or you could put the bed up and have somewhere to sit.We will not choose to stay here again, but it was a great learning experience for us as we learned to adjust our expectations and not let the bummer of a room ruin our vacation.

We stayed at this condotel end of February to mid March! What can I say?...its Hawaii, BUT our room was SMALLER THAN LIFE!Really good location, beautiful sunrises and sunset ESPECIALLY on the 10th floor. The best view i've seen in a long time!There is a "GAY" bar in the hotel, it didnt bother me being a girl, but my boyfriend found it a little uncomfortable when he heard some discussions outside the lobby. NOT SO APPROPRIATE!Other than our room being small *i mean 250 sq feet*...our trip was amazing! Lanais are always a bonus, and i will not stay at a hotel without one. Also, the full kitchen *minus the oven* was perfect and we saved a ton of $$$ on food. That is a HUGE recommendation! A lanai and a kitchen!The hotel was obviously built a while back and you can tell with the elevators and the plumbing, but those were small things we worked around and didn't let it bother us. The staff were nice. I wouldn't say they were the best, but they were informative. It would have been good if the staff greeted you with a hello once and a while. We have decided never to stay here again, because it is just too small for 2 people and 5 suitcases. But I would say we never had any SERIOUS problems with our stay!For those that do stay here, its a great location. A little far from the Int. Market Place, but with a couple HagenDaaz stores on your walk to the shops, its well worth the distance if you know what i mean! Happy travels and aloha!

Beware any rooms that have a view of Diamond Head and/or the water: you will hear every bus that travels Honolulu. Entering the small studio, we were accosted by an odor of either garbage or mildew thinly veiled with a plug-in room refresher. The A/C had to be run independently of any other appliance or else the fuses would blow. Early in the morning, the sound of garbage trucks and public transport. And then there were the roaches. On the positive side? Great location.

I did my college internship in Honolulu and rented a studio on the third floor for 14 weeks in the summer. The location could not have been better with Kapiolani Park across the street, Waikiki Beach within sight, and a great view of Diamondhead. It was also nice being on the edge of Waikiki and not in the heart of it all. The lobby was always kept clean as was the pool. The only negative I have was the gay bar on the second floor with their techno music till the late night hours. Also, as a young male, I felt visually molested by their eyes peering down from the open lanai above. Needless to say I took the long way around to get into the hotel.

The WAIKIKI GRAND has the very BEST location in all of Waikiki Beach! Make no mistake, it doesn't get any better than this! Diamond Head, Kapiolani Park, the beautiful beach and ocean are all right there! Just 50 yards to the beach...or all of about a 30 second stroll....WOW! It is a hip boutique style residential hotel with a great "beach vibe" and open air lobby with very friendly people! Each of the studio condo units are privately owned, therefore, they reflect the owner's personality and style...which I find refreshing! No cookie cutter rooms here! And many of them come complete with kitchenettes, which is another great added bonus! They are also planning upgrades to the building in the near future....so it's only going to get better and better! You can't beat the rates, either! Search all of Waikiki and you will find no greater value with such a prime beachside location...than the Waikiki Grand! We are thinking of buying a vacation unit there and worked with some great Realtors who know every unit in the bldg. and gave us wonderful insight and guidance, as they sell most all units there. So if you are looking for a great experienced real estate team, contact David & Nick, well-known as "The Dream Team" at [--] and they can help you find the best deal, for sure. We are hoping to buy a unit there, rent it out when we are not using it, then call it our "island getaway" when we stay in it. Lots of the owners do exactly this and make it a great investment. I highly recommend the Waikiki Grand! If you are adventurous and enjoy a "beachy vibe" and love experiencing something different, then the Waikiki Grand is perfect!Aloha!

This is the second time I have stayed here. My husband and daughter (9yrs) stayed here in May in 2007 in 319 - wonderful newly remodeled unit. I was a shocked it was so nice. Great location to everything. This time we booked another unit with them as we know they are remodeled to the same standard and they are so nice. We booked 918 this time. I loved this location. Great views and an entire wall of windows. These guys (the owners of 3 units here #319, 605 and 918) are so amazingly professional and accommodating. They came in and did a midstay clean. The place looks so new. So did 319. Next time I will stay in the other one. We cannot beat the price and location. We bring my daughters Razor and zip all around the beachfront. We are actually going to look at some real estate here this trip. I cannot comment on the other reviews of the front desk as we have not have to interact with them as Pam and Alice take care of every last detail. -Oh little thing about the circuit breakers, do not have every appliances and the AC running at the same time as it tripped the breaker once. The man 'Lloyd' came upstairs and fixed it straight away. Just an fyi.

At 3pm I waited over 25 miniutes for an unapoligetic clerk who simply said he was tending to something upstairs. My room was far below what was advertised on expedia.com. I was told I was being upgraded to room 419. The place was so noisey at 5 am garbage trucks empty endless trash bins located right below my window. The breakfast was mediocare not a continental breakfast but rater a boxed muffin and juice with cut fruit that was obviously not refrigerated! This place is poorly managed the room was filthy sand everywhere I couldn't go barefoot in my own room, the kitchenette was disgusting the dishes and flatware were greesy and there were roaches everywhere even in the shower.

We stayed on the Deck floor (10th flr) in 1004 and 1005. We had to take one room for 3 nights, the next for a week and back to fhe first room for our last week. This was due to our last minute booking for this vacation. We booked one room directly from the owner and the second room through the management company. Good rates for the studios.Both units were clean and well maintained. One unit was THE show place of the building. Breakfast and newspapers were delivered daily. The coin operated laundry room was located on the parking level. Our units faced the zoo and we could hear the baboons at night and early morning to add to the flavor of the islands. The beach and Kapiolani Park were one block away.We were treated well and would return.

Well located but very low service hotel. Rooms are privately owned and do not all have the same standards. When I left I asked to have a final clearance bill and they refused to provide it assuring me that I would not be billed any extra, and now that I'm back home I see that they charged a day after my departure an extra $90 that is not justified. Would certainly not go back there.

-Unit #914 is uninhabitable; the elevator nosie is constant since your unit is directly next to it, and the car arrival bell would wake the dead. What's more, the lanai door of unit #915 is directly next to your headboard, and that resident comes and goes more than the roaches and slams the door each time. I tried to speak with him about it to which he said "whatever." What's more, upon arrival; the internet didn't work; no laundry room key in the unit; no remote for the TV. Each a small issue, but combined make it a miserable experience.-Unit #409 was super! for the first two days until complete demoltion and renovation began in unti #509!!! I was offered unit #1001 as replacement...until the construction worker at least, took pity on me and warned me that unit #1002 was next to be removated that week!!!-Parking is EXACTLY what the other user said; someone always takes your stall, expecially on week-ends as Hula's patrons arrive in numbers. The front desk is helpless, and will not tow. I have adopted the habit of "borrowing" a HPD red traffic cone to mark my stall when away from the building, well, that is to say once I got a stall as my first night SOMEONE ELSE WAS IN IT!-Don the Resident Manager is a complete waste of humanity. He is inept and unable to resolve any issues.May I suggest you stay at a real Hotel, such as The Hawaii Prince as I subsequently did...

All my life wanted to visit the beautiful islands of Hawaii. Choose this particular hotel for obvious reasons. Did not complain about the pool that did not exist eventhough the website contained a photo of a beautiful pool. I was very insulted when a staff member questioned whether or not I was an actual residence of the hotel because I am an African American. I am in the process of returning to Hawaii & I make it a point to tell everyone of the rude racist behavior that I experience at this establishment. I would not stay at this terrible, run-down dirty hotel for all the tea in China!

I loved it here! I went with my brother. We stayed on the frist floor in a very nice clean room. Hula's was great! We ended up making friends, and having a blast and even went a gay catamaran tour. I would recommend this place to anyone!

Having read some rather negative reviews, we were a little concerned that we had done the right thing in booking the Waikiki Grand. But email service from the staff was very reassuring and helpful.We arrived on an early flight and, as requested, our room (911) was ready. The check in staff were very helpful.The Grand is in an excellent location if you don't want to be surrounded by the hordes. Right on a beautiful park and with stunning views of Diamond Head, the beach - magnificent sunsets (see photo) - and of course the park with a first class zoo. Being woken by real monkeys chattering rather than the human kind was a great experience!The negatives? The room was tired with second hand furniture from a church bazaar - at least it looked that way. The 'phone was useless and no bedside lamps. But we didn't really care; the location more than made up for it. After a heavy day of activity, a cold beer on the lanai and that fantastic view, nothing else mattered.We did have several occasions to call maintenance and contrary to other's reports, can only say the response was excellent - immediately fixing the problem (blocked toilet - not nice, but it does happen).While we were there, the hotel introduced continental breakfasts which was a pleasant touch. The house maids were very pleasant and our room was always clean with fresh linen. At all times, the staff were friendly and helpful.I've stayed in 5* hotels world wide. This certainly isn't one, but I'd happily go back - in fact, we are: for Christmas this year.

I booked this hotel because of its great location, then several very negative reviews appeared which made me wonder if I had made a grand mistake. We decided because of its super location across from Kapiolani Park and 1/2 block from Waikiki Beach and short walk to the Queens Surf beach and all the bus stops to keep our reservation. What we found was an amazing place!We had room 509 facing the park and the ocean. The room was very clean with tiled floor with a nice double bed and provides rollaway bed we asked for. The kitchen area was adequate and clean as was the tub/shower and toilet.We did not find anything particularly noisy, just some street sounds that is to be expected when you have a room on the traveled road side.Not other guests ever complained about any room they had.Maid service was quick everyday and we found the Desk staff to be very friendly and helpful, and especially enjoyed Hula's gay bar on the second floor and found it to to be one of the nicest bars and settings on the whole of Oahu! And would recommend it to straight or gay friends alike.Best of all is its location; everything was conveniently located or a short walk. Buses run right in front of the Hotel, taxis are easy to grab, Star Bucks is next door and the Beach across the street.It is very easy to get to H-1 (the freeway).I will most certainly recommend this Hotel, I have put it at the top of my Waikiki hotel list, and I will return again.Barry Lawrence

We booked Queen's Surf before reading all the negative reports - then panicked, finding it too late to cancel under their 21-day cancellation policy. How HAPPY we are that we adopted a 'wait and see' attitude - our room was absolutely perfect for us: clean kitchenette, clean bathroom, and a stunning view of the beach/park across the street. Yes, the floors are tile and not carpeted. Fancypants this is not. But clean, quiet, great view - and of the bars we visited in HI, Hula's 2 floors down was our favorite for great view, ambiance, and friendly folk. Everything we could've wished for... and so centrally located that we enjoyed both quiet AND walking distance proximity to beaches, attractions, and anything we wished for - even an art show in the park across the street!Fellow guests encountered at the front desk seemed equally well pleased with their rooms:we heard no reports of unsatisfactory accommodations during our stay.Queen's Surf is highly recommended; it'll be our 'place of choice' whenver we return to Oahu!

Booked 4 nights in room #319. Could only stay 2 two nights. There were roaches on the ceiling, kitchen, and bathroom floor. T.V. didn't work. Gay bar on the second floor wasn't really what I was expecting. Didn't have much luck getting a refund. Very dissappointed in the whole experience.

We booked this hotel thinking it was a three star hotel and that our room would look like the picture that Expedia displayed. We saw two rooms and took one of them only because it had a king bed and the other had a double and that was all that was left. However, the bed had been slept in and the management told me to just pull up the covers as nobody had been there very long. So at 11 PM at night I asked for clean sheets and made the bed myself. The floor was tiled but felt dirty on bare feet and the white wall tile in the bathroom was all dirty. The tub had bad stains on it. The bed was very hard and uncomfortable and the spread was worn out. The bed and one table and two chairs(only) in the room looked like old Hawaii but too old. We were on the alley side of the hotel with three windows and there was noise(dumpsters, trucks, buses)all night long. This was room 420. We noticed other rooms that the maids were cleaning and some looked a little better than ours. It seems that in Honolulu one needs to spend a lot of money on a hotel or settle for an old seedy hotel. The hallways are worn and dirty. I would not recommend this hotel to anyone even though some rooms are better than others evidently.

Note that the Waikiki Grand is a condo building. The individual units are owned by different owners that are rented out by the building management. Thus, the condition of the units, the emenities and their decor are different. This may explain the different reviews here.We have been to Honolulu many times and decided to stay at the Waikiki Grand on our recent visit (Feb. 10th 1007). The check-in counter persons were courteous; our check in and out was swift. We stayed on the 4th floor. The room was equiped with a fridge, microwave and a full kichenett (electric burners, sink, cooking utensils, pots/pans, plates, bowls, cups, knives, forks, spoons, etc. etc.), diswasher detergent, coffee maker and coffee packages. In addition to eating out, we used the kitchen quite a bit.The entire one side of the room was windows from top to bottom with double pane glass. It also has a temperature controled air conditioning unit. We like the breeze so we opened the windows most of our stay to allow the island air to circle the room. The room has recessed lighting in several places - a nice touch. The floor of the entire room and the bathroom is marble (or marble like?). It's a nice alternative from the usual carpet. The king size bed was comfortable.Room has TV and VCR player, alarm clock. Hot/cold water pressure was excellent.Breakfast (a muffin, croissant, fresh cut fruits and juice) were delivered daily with newspaper to our room. Room was serviced daily and towels (including soaps/shampoo) were replenished.Overall, our stay was pleasant. No issues or problems. It's "Avove Average" in the dollar/price range and its class of accomodation. We certaintly would stay there again!Likes:Great location; steps from the beach/park/zooNice comfortable roomHula bar on the second floor80% straight shop in the lobbyGreat views from the 10th floor sundeck (you can sun tan there)Dislikes:No free wi-fi (though you can get free-wifi at hula bar)Pool is of no use (it's in a shaded area behind Teddy's burger).

My husband and I just spent 5 nights at the Waikiki Grand Hotel. I read every review before we left, and that is the problem. I read each of these reviews but I did not listen to them. I rationalized with thoughts such as: We do not need service; we do not care about a view; we do not expect anything from the hotel except a place to lay our heads in the evening; who knows these reviews may have been written by the competition… Here is our experience: Hotel location is excellent. We never saw the pool, with a beautiful beach across the street and a pool at home - we could not care less about a hotel pool. Never saw the sun deck, we did not need it or care about it. The hotel staff was friendly and courteous. We never saw the Gay Bar; we have no issues with gay people, and there were no more obviously gay people in and around this hotel than anywhere else; most certainly they were not offensive. We had a city-view, which was not beautiful, but not a problem since we were gone from 8:00 a.m. until after dark. Our room was spacious enough, clean on the surface, some updates, such as nice tile floors, stainless steel refrigerator, granite counter top, stone back-splash, nice tile around tub. Sheets were clean and fresh, pillows were terrific, soft, clean. The bed was extremely comfortable. When we arrived in our room, we said: Okay, this is fine; this is what we would expect from a two-star hotel, and for the price—this will work well for a few days. Clearly, we understand the meaning of a 2-star hotel and the difference between this and a 5-star; perhaps those reviewers just have not traveled as much as we have. Then I saw the first one and absolutely nothing else mattered: a roach in the sink. Then I saw another in the bath basin; then several more in the bathroom, then more coming out of the trim. We complained at the desk and were given a can of “Hot Shot” roach and ant spray. The next day we asked for more spay and were told they had no more and that all hotels have roaches. The next day, we went to the grocery store and purchased more spray. This seemed to drive them out of the cracks and crevices and we had roaches on our phone, radio, on the doors, even one on the drapes. We were then down to one more night so we just toughed it out. We should have left as soon as we saw the first one. We thought it was an isolated incident and never dreamed we would be overtaken.As I said in the previous paragraph, nothing else mattered. I could not even drink a cup of coffee in this room, coffee that was purchased around the corner at a popular franchise coffee shop, much less eat the breakfast that was brought to our room each morning. I kept my clothes, makeup, flat iron, toothbrush and virtually everything else sealed in the bags in which I packed and took out only what I needed as I needed it. After we returned home, we left everything in the garage and disinfected each item piece by piece, including our baggage.In the future, we will pay strict attention to the comments of fellow travelers and not believe we know it all. Also in the future, if this is what the budget will allow, we will stay home.

If you are a gay beach fan, this little gem is conveniently located across the street from the gay beach on Queen's Surf. There's also Hula's right downstairs on the second floor where you can get your gay cocktails on after the beach (Sun afternoons are fabulous). This was our third visit to Honolulu and my first review of the hotel. The hotel itself is OK. It's a little dated but the condo rooms have been renovated in many cases. Ours was incredibly tiny with no place to store our roller boards but it had been renovated with marble-esque tile in the bathroom and an updated kitchenette complete with LCD TV. We really could have used a radio/CD player. There was none to be found anywhere in the room. I blew the dust off the Gloria Gaynor CD for this trip and found that there was no where to play it. Our oceanview lanai overlooked Diamond head. Definitely the best feature of the room. The worst feature of the room was an air conditioner which was one of those window units installed right at the headboard of our queen size bed. Kind of loud right by head every night. Also very cold. I was gracious enough to let the boyfriend sleep on the other side of the bed because she complains a lot when the temperature is not to her liking. They've added a comp (or should I say camp?) continental breakfast delivey @ 8am. That was a nice touch. So girls if you're in Waikiki for the beach and not necessarily the luxury, I wholeheartedly recommend the Queens Surf. Who sits around in the room all day anyway?

We hated this hotel. As we got in we were greeted by a Security Guard who didn't even understand English ! We had five uninvited guests (Cockroaches) waiting for us in the room !! The washroom looked nothing like the photos ... I've seen better washrooms in third world countries !! The room we had looked nothing like the photos, the bed sheets were dirty and the bed was just discussing !!! With the help of Expedia we got a refund and moved to the Sheraton a few blocks down. Expedia was very supportive and gave us an excellent service !

I had a great time in Hawaii this past trip and thought that the Hotel I stayed at "The Waikiki Grand Hotel" was a great place to stay. I have read these reviews and was weary, but when I got in the room it was very clean and the Ocean View was great! I would definetely stay here again! The crew they got working there are awesome! They helped me with all my questions and where I wanted to go. Thanks guys. Aloha!

I stayed at the Waikiki Grand from August 1 -13th, unfortunately.It was was WORSE experience I have ever had. The condominium was filthy. The manager, Miho, was unresponsive. The first two days I spent cleaning the apartment. A few days after I was there, I flushed the toilet and all the feces from flusing the toilet came up in the bathtub.The next day, when the bathtub backup up again, I called the Department of Health. Manny, one of the staff members, screamed at me for calling the Health Dept.Because I had paid for the two weeks in advance, I was not able to get a refund. When I asked to be moved to another hotel, there was no response.

There are definite plusses and minuses about the Waikiki Grand. If you're used to staying at the Hilton, you'll definitely feel like you've stepped down. If you're used to Motel 6, you'll absolutely love it. If you're used to mid-level hotels, you'll probably like it. Overall, it's a decent hotel: functional and kind of charming decor, relatively clean, and when it comes to location, it's one of the best places we've stayed in Oahu.My husband and I had an Ocean View room -- #611 -- with a spectacular view of Diamond Head and (of course) the ocean. Housekeeping was good but not perfect; the only "gross-out" moment was on the last day of our 7-day trip, when I thought I'd try the coffeemaker only to find out that the housekeeper hadn't cleaned out the filter from the last guest. Otherwise, the room itself was fine. We had a tile floor, so we bought flip-flops for walking around the room since we usually tracked at least a little sand in from the beach.Service was hit-or-miss. I wouldn't say they had the "Aloha spirit," but they were friendly enough. Slow, though, and they tended to run out of beach towels. And, despite the threats of towing, when someone was parked in our spot, they just shrugged it off and said we could park in any open spot.If street noise bothers you, you should think about another hotel. This hotel borders one of the busiest streets in Waikiki -- not in terms of foot traffic, but rather cars, busses, trucks, etc. We slept with our window open because air conditioning affects our sinuses, but we're okay with street noise. The gay bar on the 2nd floor was not nearly as noisy as we thought it would be given how popular it is -- the building-wide lanai is always packed -- although we're really glad we weren't on the 3rd floor. The only time it was a bother was on Friday night, when for some reason there was a lot of yelling between the lanai and passer-bys on the street. As with the street noise, if alternative lifestyles bother you, think about another hotel.The usual line is, "You don't go to Oahu to stay in your room," and we didn't. There's so much to see and do -- especially when you have a car and can travel all over the island any time you want to -- that we were rarely in the room. However, when we did choose to stay in, we were comfortable -- no weird smells, no funk on the sofa, no icky feeling from the bedsheets, etc. Our trip was amazing, and the hotel didn't detract from it at all. In fact, the location was a major bonus for us. We would stay there again.

I am a resident of Hawaii and I am embarrassed by the lack of customer service at the Waikiki Grand Hotel. Waikiki was booked and no hotel rooms were available. Since our favorite hotels were full, we booked 2 nights through a travel engine on the internet . Never staying at the Waikiki Grand Hotel, we didn't know what to expect. I called ahead to alert them that we were going to arrive late in the evening. When we got there, we were confused by the Private Parking signs under the hotel, but parked anyway thinking it was for hotel guests. Out of the elevator the 3 of us adults came (me+hubby+daughter), only to see the Front Desk clerk say goodbye to the Security Guard, even tho she sees us arriving. We were greeted by the Security Guard with a, "Driver's license, please." Where's the aloha in that? Then we asked if we could park downstairs. He put the fear of God in us and said to move it immediately if you don't want your car to be towed away. We had to park across at the zoo or 5 blocks away. We ended up in the latter. Now it's 10:30p and we go up to the room where there's only a king bed ... for 3 adults? Hmmm, let's go back to the Front Desk. I explain the situation, he puts up both hands and says he can't do anything because he's only a security guard and he doesn't work for the hotel. There's also no manager until 9 am the next morning. By this time, steam hits the top of my head and I find myself yelling at the guard. All of a sudden he gets a brilliant idea to check the computer and call the FD clerk that left earlier. Luckily there was one more room that might be empty and daughter could sleep there until other accommodations could be made in the morning.To make a long story short, we got another room with a less than acceptable futon and double bed for the next night - hardly worth the money I was paying for. The parking nightmare never ended because the zoo, as well as other parking structures, were always full . No manager ever contacted us to make amends which goes to prove that there was no aloha extended at the Waikiki Grand Hotel. Don't stay there. Go elsewhere.

Great ViewVery affordabenice staffcleanI was treated so well at this hotel I have to recommend it. The Ocean View rooms seem to be the best value. For about $10 more per night you can get an oceanview instead of looking at a bunch of buildings. If you stay for 7 days the price is almost cut in half per night.

Although there are mixed reviews of the Waikiki Grand, I believe that if you get the right room, you will have the best bargain in Waikiki. We stayed in Room 908 which is the Direct Ocean View unit run by Waikiki Retreat. The view is absolutely magnificent. The only thing between the room and the ocean view is a small slice of queen kapiolani park (and the room is way above the treetops). the ocean can be seen from every part of the condo (except the bathroom). There is also a stunning view of Diamond Head. Being so high up and off the main road, its fairly quiet--we could not hear the bar on the 2nd floor.The unit is competely renovated with a/c, tile floors, a murphy bed and a small updated kitchen. bathroom is also clean and neat. The whole unit is very stylish. It took us a while to figure out how to boil water on the cooktop but we were successful. A definite plus to be able to cook in the room--there is a grocery store about a mile away (we reserved a parking space in the hotel so had access to a car).The beach is a two minute walk--extremely convenient. The only slight negative is that it is small so its only suitable for singles or couples. But that is understandable for the price. we paid about $125/night including all taxes which I think is reasonable for the views. The lobby is perfectly nice, the elevators and hallways aren't as attractive but this room is spectacular. Highly recommended.

Room 511 was NOT suitable for us at even $100/night. We would have left immediately had it not been a late-night arrival. My parents were in room 914 for the same $100 and they had a bargain as it's bigger, had marble floors and unlike our room, they saw no cockroaches.The higher you get in the hotel the nicer it is. the rooms WITHOUT views are DIRE. stay away at all costs. The night watchman is the only help after hours and he only comes by the desk every 20 minutes. There's a walkie-talkie on the desk he said we should have used despite it being labeled 'for emergencies only.' All those flowers you see in the website photos are the same 2 bouquets. No flowers in the room as advertised.Room 511 had a lanai that appeared never to have been washed, tiles falling off, doors that wouldn't close, the fridge defrosted causing a flood for us to clean up, we spotted 5 different cockroaches in the room.... there is a 1 inch gap under most of the doors in the hotel so it must be a bug superhighway. The bed smelled of cologne. The elevators are creepy, the gay bar on floor 2 is VERY busy and therefore there's a steady stream of heavily perfumed people running around. If you're perfume allergic: Stay Away. PARKING IS A NIGHTMARE. The lot is too small and if there aren't spots you are directed to other hotel parking lots a good walk away. Add $10/day to the price for parking.The plus side: great to be on this side of waikiki overlooking the zoo. They were willing to negotiate to $100 per room a week from high season. A couple of the rooms may be nice below but stay on the 9th floor or above is our suggestion. The nice gal at the front desk refunded our money graciously. For $10 more per night we moved to the Beachcomber and were MUCH relieved and preferred being able to walk to better food (Moana Surfrider Veranda).

I just graduated from college and went to Honolulu for my trip! This hotel was pretty decent for what we paid. Keep in mind that each room is different. They are all owned seperately so some rooms are kept better than others. We stayed in room 714. It had perfect A\C, a beautiful view of diamond head and the water, a microwave, 2 stove burner, small fridge, and a sink. The bed was kind of hard but we slept just find. Yes, there is a gay bar and a gay store in the lobby. Plus, it was gay pride week. Even at that my boyfriend didn't mind too much and he's pretty uncomfortable with the subject. This is a great spot for younger people. It's right by the bus line so you can get to the other side of town. We didn't rent a car and never had to take a taxi. It's at the end of the strip so you have to walk about 10 minutes to get to the heart of town. There is a great beach with a rock barrier about 3 minutes from the hotel. Good for kids or people afraid of sharks. On the weekend you can walk to Art on the Zoo fence. I bought a bunch of local art and there were local crafts and jewelry as well. I've been to Maui 3 times and Honolulu is much different! It is very much like a big city. A lot less relaxing than maui but there are a lot of things to do. If you are a big shopper like me you'll love it on Oahu. If you want privacy and less crying children on the beach head to Maui. Aloha!!!

The outside of the htoel looks okay, but the second you get on the elevator things only get worse. We had a decent view if the park, but there was a busy avenue right below the windows. We stayed on the fourth floor and the gay bar two floors down was loud until about 3 am on the weekend. Buses start up early, as well as street cleaners, and traffic in general. Even heard a homeless man pushing his cart by. There was a group of 7 loud, drunk guys outside until 4 in the morning with a prostitute, and someone else got beat up, which brought sirens and more noise. This avenue seemed full of drunks. This is a big deal when there is no air conditioning and the windows must remain open. Do not plan on getting any solid sleep and don't plan on sleeping past 6 am. The bed was cheap, the sheets smelled. I took the bedspread off and walked it down to make sure it was replaced. The lanai was gross, the bathroom was gross, the carpet looked and felt gross. This place is very dirty. It is also VERY overpriced. There are hotels closer to prime areas that are cheaper and MUCH cleaner. The zoo is also nearby, and I could smell faint animal smells. The pullout bed was a bunch of plywood nailed into a frame and a lumpy mattress was on top, with no blankets. At least you'll make yourself go out and do something, because very few people woulod intentionally stay there loger than they have to. I'm not picky, just like to get my money's worth. Stayed in a much better place in 2005, for the same money.

We stayed at the Waikiki Grand Hotel from Dec 29-Jan 5, 2006 and were pretty happy with our selection. We booked the room through a vacation rental website and did not realize that it was a hotel that catered to gay and lesbian couples and needless to say, my husband was not too happy when he found out.However, for only $100 a night (during new years) and to be right across the street from the beach, we were EXTREMELY happy with the hotel. Our room was actually a studio condo and was neat and tidy as advertised. We even had a stove, fridge, toaster and dishes, which was extremely nice. We hit the ABC stores multiple times for breakfast and snack foods so we did not have to eat out all the time. (another bonus is the Starbucks right there on the corner)The staff was extremely friendly at the Waikiki Grand and we never had a problem getting beach towels or chairs – they don’t even charge you for them like some of the bigger hotels. It was a simple hotel – no extras, but a good deal for the price.As far as the gay and lesbian scene – yes, there is a bar on the 2nd floor that caters to gay and lesbian couples, but we never felt uncomfortable during our stay. We saw many different types of people staying at the hotel, from younger, straight couples such as ourselves, to retirees, and families.The only negative during our stay was the location of our room. Our room faced the alley and since there are no “real windows” in the room, the noise from the street carried up to our room and we were woken up on a couple of different occasions in the wee-hours of the morning.The hotel is at the end of the Waikiki strip, but in easy walking distance to all of Waikiki’s beaches and shopping. We found many great places to eat and there are PLENTY of places to shop. The hotel is also across the street from the Zoo and Kapiolani Park. For the adventurous souls, you can take a long walk/jog all the way up to the top of Diamond Head for spectacular views. (make sure you do this early in the morning before it gets too hot)We also took the advice of another travler and made reservations at the Top of Waikiki for their sunset dinner - great advice. The food was excellent and the sunset was amazing.Happy traveling!

My husband and I were a little leary of staying in this hotel, especially after reading some of the reviews on this site. After calling about room reservations, we were told that they couldn't give us a room number until check-in, but that we did have one of the better rooms. We wound up with room 911, which was wonderful!The view was great from the balcony, over the zoo, out towards diamond head, and right toward the ocean. You also overlook a park where we watched school groups eat and families play. Since he was there on business and I met him there for 3 days, we weren't in the hotel that much, which is how it should be for someone travelling to Hawaii. The room was great -- we had a coffee maker, refrigerator, microwave. The TV was small, but we never turned it on anyway. The room wasn't large, either, but for the two of us, as little as we were there, it was fine. We also realized on the second day that maid service is better if you tip. There was some balcony construction going on in the room above us, but there were signs warning us and encouraging hotel guests to schedule activities out of the hotel during certain hours (again, you're in Hawaii, who's going to be in the hotel all day??). Overall, a much better experience than expected, especially for the reasonable price.

To anyone thinking of staying at this hotel, all I can say is "buyer beware". I was a repeat customer at this hotel and thought that we would try it again. After making an internet reservation though the Waikiki Grand website (they also go by the name of Queen Surf Rentals), we received an email confirmation to stay in Room 911 (one of their top-rated and nicest rooms). My wife and I (yes, we knew that it was gay-friendly, but that doesn't bother us as we're open minded Canadians) were very much looking forward to spending time in Room 911 as it is often described as one of the best in the hotel. When we arrived around 12:30 a.m. of January 23, I was greeted by a security person who not only couldn't find my confirmation, but also had difficulty communicating in simple English. After spending almost half an hour searching around the offices and making phone calls, it was finally discovered that my room was rented out due to "an emergency". Excuse me??!! The whole premise behind a reservation confirmation is to actually hold that room, not rent it out. Instead of enjoying a romantic 2 days in room 911, my wife and I were given room 509. Hardly the same room and quite frankly, a room that I wouldn't let my worst enemy stay in. Dingy, drab, and noisy. The next morning, we were moved to room 1002. Roomier and a nice view from the balcony. But the furniture was dirty and the place overall lacked any of the character, romance, or ambiance that we had looked forward to.  Quite frankly, I don't think these people can be trusted. No one ever bothered to contact me to explain why we were not given room 911 or offer any sort of apology or explanation. As far as I'm concerned, they breached the contract that we agreed to.

-the '12 and '14 units are next to the elevators, vibrations will keep you awake.-'08 thru '16 have ocean views ('16 no lanai).-some have kitchen, some not; some have a tub, some not; some are renovated, some not.-prices vary wildly, depending on where you get them: Queens Surf Vacation Rental is the most expensive, and shows pics of room "categories." Waikikigrand.com gives actual pics of actual rooms with actual amenities, but web site prices DO NOT match what they will "quote" you!!!-The best rates are to be found at VRBO.com, Craigslist.com, or Yahoo search engine which will turn up gems such as Waikikiretreat.com.-Oh, sundeck suite 1003 is a dump, 1004 is renovated and nice, 1005 is fabulous but too expensive, 1009 is large, private.-Parking is limited, $8 a day, and many times I came home to find someone else parked in my stall! -Many units have wireless internet, as does Hula's so all you need is your laptop, and configure it to pick up someone else's signal.

As the rooms in this hotel have different individual owners, the standards are also different. We had room 614 which was roomy, clean, good size bathroom, TV, fridge, coffee maker...all the things you would expect. Great view over the zoo to Diamond Head and the beach. Great for gay travellers as the best gay bar in Hawaii (Hula's) is located on the 2nd floor and Queen's beach is just a few minutes walk. Will stay there again next year.

I stayed in #1009 (penthouse/roof). It was truly paradise. Unbelievable view of the beach and Diamond Head in one stunning panorama. Tans look great against the white sheets, gentle trade winds blowing through the louvered windows. A quick walk to Waikiki Beach to surf, snorkle, and sun; to Kalakaua Avenue with shops and restaurants, or to Kapialani Park & Zoo. The unit was roomy, no fighting for bathroom (2) and had a kitchenette for making quick snacks, with fridge for cold beer to enjoy on the lanai while watching the sunset. While there I watched movies on the big screen on the beach, saw & bought from the art fair in the park, attended the Spam Festival on Kalakaua. Didn't ever need the car. Next time won't even rent one.....just shuttle down from the airport. Can't say enough about it.....it was an incredible stay!

This place is old and run down - OK if you are trying to save a lot of money - but stay next door at the Queen Kapiolani if that is the case. Also, this place caters to those engaging in "alternative" lifestyles - so beware if you are bringing the kids, and you do not want them exposed to this.

I recently stayed at a wonderful location in the Waikiki area. I have stayed at several locations in Waikiki from Hilton Vacation Village($269) to the Sheraton properties ($185-$374). I have also stayed in several properties away from the beach (4-5 blocks $97-$145) The Waikiki Grand Hotel is a smaller hotel with the best location for your vacation dollars. The room I stayed in (618) was recently upgraded with a Hawaiian/tropical flair. This studio/room was fantastic. It has a view of the City/Diamond Head. The room's decor was similar to other rooms costing $190 or more in the area. The room was immaculate. Imagine awaking to the sounds of the beach life at your door step. The property is just steps from the hottest corner in Waikiki, the beach, Starbucks and great dining. The room and property in general are in great condition and are a great bargin.

Walked in and cut a deal for nearly 1/2 off the rack rate in suite 1002 (sundeck suite). Ok the room was a bit dusty but clean, one suite was being renovated on the floor, but omigawd the view! Facing Kapiolani Park and the Beach, we spent most of our time lounging on the sundeck, night and day, when we were home. If you can tolerate the confusion at the front desk, which was considerable, you can score a good deal here. Saw suite 1005 online, looks like an even better deal. At the far south end of Waikiki, but better for highway access.

My partner and I stayed here for 4 nights in May of 2005. Let me start by saying the location is amazing! This is by far, the best aspect of the hotel. Based on the description of the room on the website and other guest reviews, we were expecting much more. We did have a nice visit to Honolulu but just felt the hotel was a little underwhelming. While the staff was not rude, they were not particularly that friendly. Manny however was nice and helpful. I could not help but feel the rooms were slightly dirty. The shower curtain in Room 409 absolutely needs to be changed. I will say that the price of $115 seems quite good for what we received. I think the next time, we will stay at a place a little more upscale. Thanks!

I had a great experience here, during my first visit to Waikiki. I had a city view room, and I didn't feel like I was missing out because I couldn't see the ocean. Our room was very clean, and had much more character than a boring generic hotel. The bamboo bed frame and feather comforter were a nice touch, in addition to the nice amenities in the room such as fridge and coffeemaker.The location was great; there is only one street between the hotel and the beach. I also liked the area much better than some of the other areas of Waikiki. It's at the end of the strip but seemed a close walk to everything. It was awesome to have Hula's bar right downstairs, too.Staying here felt like a treat, and it seemed a real bargain compared to the prices of comparable rooms. I don't get to vacation often, and this place offered exactly what I wanted.

My wife and I stayed here in 1999. The first room we were assigned was terrible. It was sooooo small that there was no room for our suitcases and the TV sat sideways to the bed. The bed sank in the middle, the so called beach view was by looking at an angle out the window behind the TV. Room also sat just over a bus stop so that was heard all the time as was the early morning soda truck delivery with the loud roll-up doors. I am not one to complain as like most, I don't expect to spend much time in the room. However, I was feeling that I had nowhere nice to escape for rest or if the weather turned bad. We went to the front desk and the next day they were nice enough to get us in a suite on the roof for the same price, which was a 1000% improvement. Much larger, full regrigerator, dining table, microwave, sofa.I rate the help of the staff really high (again that was in 99)Without the first room I would rate it much higher in value. With the risk of that included I must rate it neutral.

We stayed at this hotel for 17 days. The staff was wonderful, but the hotel itself was just "ok". We had problems with noise all night long on one floor. People coming and going and doors slamming. When we said something to the staff, we were told that they were washing clothes. Everynight, I don't think so. So we didn't get much sleep here. The view from the balcony was fabulous but we had to switch rooms half way through due to the longer stay and they were booked up for Pro Bowl. We had no view except the back of a building from here. The pool was not working the whole time and we were not compensated for it in any way. The cleaning was not good iether. As they are owned by other people and just rented out, the cleaning is pretty much up to you. They will make the beds but that is just about it. There is not any restaraunt in this hotel at all and the bar is not what we expected and would not go there again. Would not stay here again unless we have to.

Our first trip to Waikiki Beach was great after checking into our nice room on the 4th floor overlooking the park and Waikiki Beach. The manager, Liz, was very helpful. We stayed in room 409 which was decorated in Thai Bali style and very romantic. We are looking forward to our next trip and will book this room again. We found this room at the gayhawaii.com/grandwaikiki website. The hotel has a "boutique" flavor . Aloha.

Have been to Hawai'i 7 times and have stayed anywhere from $75 to $400 plus rooms. The location is the best in Waikiki I think. Ask for an OCEANVIEW room, and one that has been renovated. You have the best view in Honolulu (direct view of the Park and Diamondhead, and across the street from the Park beaches...absolutely one of the best views in Hawaii. I generally do not care for Honolulu, but when I have a day or two, I will stay here. YOU NEED TO CALL IN ADVANCE AND RESERVE YOUR PARKING WITH THE HOTEL AS IT IS LIMITED. There is a gay bar on the 2nd floor, that is filled with locals. I don't think that straight families would have any issues, (I didn't) but if you are a homophobe stay elsewhere. Also, you need to know that a portion of this is apartments for 20 somethings. That is why you should BE SURE to request an oceanview room. These are the true hotel rooms. The location can absolutely NOT be beat. If you have teen children who want to roam, (WITHOUT YOU) the main drag of Waikiki is here, and the beach, park, zoo, and aquarium are right across the street. Would recommend this hotel and will be staying here again. The rooms are small. Don't expect a room the size of a Hampton Inn or a business hotel. This is Hawai'i. Rooms at at a premium, and if you want a very elaborate room, go elsewhere....and expect to pay a lot more. Rooms hold 2 people comfortably...any more than that you would be pushing it. If you want to go to the beach and roam around Waikiki, then this is perfect for you.

I recently stayed in a hotel that I enjoyed and I felt I would share this hotel jewel for anyone wanting affordable lodging in Waikiki with spectacular views. The location can't be beat. It is in the the recently renovated Waikiki Grand. I strongly recommend staying in unit 911. Being on a higher floor, you had no street nosies, just supurb scenery. It had breathtaking views of the Ocean and Diamond head. It is the last building near the corner of Kalakaua and Kapahulu, so you have an unobstructed view from your bed and lanai overlooking the lush greenness of Kapiolani park and you can have a beautiful view of the beach from this room. I can't say enough about this view because it has to be one of the best in Waikiki.The beach across the street is Queen's surf beach and the city has just completed new landscaping and paving so there is a beautiful new promenade to walk along . Also on weekends they have Free movies on the beach there. They set up a 50 foot screen and everyone gathers on the beach and buys food from the stands located temporarily for the show. You can even watch the movies from the Lanai of the room I was in. The 24 hour fitness facility is just around the corner on Kalakaua. So entertainment, shopping, movies, botanic gardens, aquarium, zoo are all within a 15 minute walk!There is a Denny's and Starbuck's on the corner, it is also where the bus from the airport stops. The Lyon Arboretum and its rainforest palm collection is a 5 minute bus ride away. You can stay at the Queens surf and have no need for a car rental. But if you do want to rent a car and explore the other parts of this beautiful island, there is parking underground here. That is very important because parking spaces are very rare in Waikiki and so it is difficult to find a space if it isn't provided and they ticket and tow readily in Waikiki.The Queens surf is a vacation rentals type of lodging.. These units are in the Waikiki Grand hotel and vary in size, view and price. Most of the units have been remodeled and have gorgeous limestone floors with track lighting, new tropical furniture, crown moldings and look very fresh and upscale. They all come with a refrigerator, coffee maker, beautiful duvet covered beds that are changed daily! The rooms are spotless!! There is a new fantastic laundry facility in the basement with a free color TV and large folding areas. The ocean is across the street. There is also an open air limestone floored lobby and it is a great place to sit and watch people.Besides from the best location and best view, friendly service and spotless rooms, the thing that makes this place outstanding is the price. The prices vary depending on how long you are staying, if you need a full kitchen, or want that million dollar view of the extinct diamond head looming over the lush tropical greenness of the zoo and Kapiolani park. Rooms go for between $60-$125/night. That is incredible! Just explain to one of the people at the front desk your needs, (Liz is great) if you are on a budget or whether you want to go all out and they will make sure that you get a wonderful room at the absolute BEST value. For the view, cleanliness, location, facilities, and price it is unbeatable. I've had friends that have been back twice and with those prices were able to stay longer the second time and really felt at home, comfortable, beautiful views, everything a convenient short walk away. It made for a very enjoyable vacation. With all the upgrading and new landscaping the city has provided to the nearby area, this part of Honolulu has become wonderful. Perfect for sunning, swimming, socializing and shopping. It is not grass-shack-isolated-tropical luxuriance, but it is big city fun, excitement, activities, cleanliness, safe friendly and Great prices.

First, re one of the earlier reviews...Queens' Surf (in the Waikiki Grand building) is NOT the only gay-owned property in the neighborhood. However, it is the only one (in my opinion) with the best location. The check-in process at the front desk was the same as any hotel with friendly and courtesy service. But do not consider booking anything but an ocean-view room, which actually faces the park more than the ocean. The view from you balcony of Diamond Head every morning as you have coffee and the view of the surfers returning to their cars in the evening is well worth the small difference in price from the city view room. The imaculately clean and white studio we had (#414) was perfect with a tidy kitchenette with every possible item of utensils, dinnerware and cookware...plus a coffee pot and microwave and fridge. We do agree with the earlier review that there is some noise from the elevator, but that happens in any hotel. We requested, and received promptly from the front desk, a small fan which we turned on at night to mask outside noise. It worked perfectly and our sleep in the very comfortable bed was undisturbed until the sun started streaming in the next morning. Hulas, the largest gay bar in town, was on the second floor but the music from the club never disturbed us. In fact, we could not hear it even when we were on the balcony. And it was very convenient to pop in for a drink or a cruise whenever we wished. Queens' Surf beach is a 5-minute walk away and the execellent and very-gay-friendly W Hotel bar is a 10-minute walk. Situated on the far East end of the the main drag in Waikiki, the property is out of the press of the main tourist trade. Whenever you are ready to head to the beach, the front desk hands out large towels and beach chairs. They are yours for the day free of charge. There is also a large and recently renovated coin laundry room in the basement with new washers and dryers that have digital timers, plus a large flat-screen TV to help pass the time. This property was the perfect place to relax, play, or just enjoy the best of the beach and the city. We will be back every February for at least a week.

This is a great location and the price is good. The front desk staff are very friendly but completely incompetent. The maid service is terrible. If you want good service and a clean room do not stay here.

This hotel is what the "everyday real family" is looking for. The price was great, the view was great, and the location couldn't be better!! The zoo/park is across the street, and the ocean is right there to enjoy also!!! There is a fast food resturant in the hotel (great low cost prices), and a convience store is right next to the hotel. It is also right on the bus line, in case a person didn't rent a car. Staying at this hotel means not having to spend all your precious time walking to get to all the places that are eithor in or right next to this hotel, and you don't have to spend all of your vaction money on overpriced hotels that still, when it gets down to it, just gives a family a place to sleep. The rooms were nice and clean, and the staff was went above what was expected, to help us out with questions about the island !! We will stay here again someday!!!

we couldn't have been more happy with our stay... one of the best kept secrets on waikiki... great location, directly across the street from beautiful kapiolani park... our recently remodeled studio unit was comfortable and stylish... but it was the post card perfect view that made it so special... not only the pacific, but a spectacular and unobtructed view of diamond head on the other side of the park.

I stayed at Queen's Surf, Room 714, for two weeks in November 2003. I chose that hotel over others because I was able to get a great view of Diamond Head, the Honolulu Zoo, Kapapilani Park and the beach for much less than other hotels in the area. The room had been recently revamped and was quite large. The bathroom was very nice as well. Surprisingly, they had very nice soaps, shampoos and conditioners in the room every day. We had an opportunity to talk with the front desk staff and the resident manager. Both were very accomodating and helpful. However, that is where my compliments stop. For starters, you need to know that this is the only gay owned and operated hotel on the strip, and as such, you have alternative clientele. I never felt uncomfortable because of it, but it's not everyone's cup of tea. Secondly, the hotel is old and the walls are VERY, VERY thin. My room was adjacent to the elevator shaft and I could hear the elevator all the time and the "ding" every time the door opened. I could also hear my neighbor's alarm clock going off, my neighbor's phone ringing and most of the conversations that went on in the hallway. The weekend road noise was a bit much... but then again, I should have expected it. The hotel is right at the end of the main strip in Honolulu. We could also clearly hear the monkeys in the zoo calling at all hours. I ended taking a sleeping pill and putting a towel at the bottom of my door each night and that helped with the sound issue a lot. The bed wasn't terribly comfortable either, but I am not a fan of hard beds. If you don't mind them, you won't be bothered by this one. There is daily maid service, but we had to leave a note asking her to change the sheets. She didn't always sweep/vacuum the floor either so we had some left over sand on the floor most days. Overall, I would recommed this hotel if you are a person who uses hotels to simply "crash" at the end of the night and you're not picky about the creature comforts. If you have an expectation of what a "nice" hotel should be, stay somewhere else. If you are traveling on business, pick some place else. This really isn't the right hotel for you. If you have questions, please email. I hope this was helpful!

I was very pleased with my stay in Hawaii. For what I payed for a large studio with a beautiful view in Hawaii, in NYCity would have been a small closet. I was very pleased with the prices. The location is great too, walking distance from all kinds of things to do. I felt very comfortable in my room and plan on going back next year.

Queen's Surf is a nice, small company in a great location. We actually were on our honeymoon and everyone greeted us with a warm welcome and congratulations. They even helped us find a great restaraunt and gave us many tips on where to go. We felt very at home and comfortable. we would recommend to everyone.

I come twice a year for a week retreat. Since my first stay in the year 2002 Queens Surf has dramatically changed! The hotel management is now at the ground floor front desk of Waikiki Grand which it used to be on the 8th floor. I find that great because they have someone working there almost 24hours a day. The new staff are wonderful and the rooms are always very peaceful. I think the new managers name is Liz she couldn't of made are stay more enjoyable with the daily paper on are door step and even a free mai tai drink at Hulas. This will always be my place for a great vacation treat.

The Waikiki Grand Hotel has the best location in Waikiki Beach, at the best prices!!! Located at the east end of Waikiki, which is now highly desirable, the rooms overlook Diamond Head, Kapiolani Park, and panoramic views of the beach and ocean beyond. Most of the rooms have been purchased and converted into studio units and are now privately owned. It's like "home away from home" with many more amenities than major hotels, at a fraction of the cost! Great restaurants and great shopping all close by! Great gay bar, "Hula's", located on the 2nd floor. International customer base. Great place for gay men to stay! Beautiful lobby, and many more upgrades currently underway! I highly recommend it to everyone! If you want a great place in the heart of all the action, the Waikiki Grand is it! Super friendly atmosphere and a great place to have the vacation of your dreams...at an affordable price! Aloha!!David Robins

Queens Surf Vacation Rentals are rooms scattered about the 1960s built Waikiki Grand. The view of Diamond Head from our room could not be bettered, but the room was small, the a/c noisy, the Venetian blinds did not work and the balcony furniture was filthy. We paid USD 90 + tax. which was not good value for money. We would not stay in this accommodation again.

Perfect location: Kapiolani Park across the street as well as the beach. Our room, however, was tiny but clean. The lanai was a joke as the view was out the back of the hotel looking at other hotels and a trash dumpster. Incredibly noisy and the trash truck came by early every morning it seemed. Rooms on the front side may be better. After a week here we had claustrophobia! Don't expect it to be like the rooms to which you are accustomed on the mainland.
